description.plain: Quasimoto (also known as Lord Quas) is the alter ego and side project of hip-hop producer Madlib, from Oxnard, California. Quas is known for the raised pitch of his voice that sounds like he’s inhaling helium. Another notable characteristic is Quas inter-changing with Madlib’s voice. One day in the studio, Madlib decided to rap to his own beats. He didn’t like the sound of his voice (his friends in Oxnard call him ‘Barry White’ in reference to his deep voice), so he decided to slow his recorder down, rap slow, then speed the recording back up to produce Quasimoto’s distinctive high-pitched voice.

songs.title: Planned Attack

description.plain:
The lead single off the third studio release from Madlib’s high-pitched alter-ego.  A collection of 12 previously-unreleased and out-of-print tracks, Yessir Whatever spans the last 12 years of the West Coast artist’s career.

Over a droning, string-sampled beat, Lord Quas explains why he and Madlib are the hottest duo in the game, while threatening the careers of well-wishing whack rappers.

The Madlib-produced track samples a variety of bangers from different eras of hip-hop, including the works of Busta Rhymes, Big Daddy Kane, and Brand Nubian.

songs.title: Real Eyes

description.plain:
Lord Quas calls out fake gangsta rappers that don’t respect the artform, over a beat from an obscure Italian library record.

Incorporates lyrics from several Funkmaster Flex freestyles, all taken from 1998’s 60 Minutes Of Funk Volume III mixtape. Also features “My Flows is Tight” by Lord Digga and what sounds like a snippet of ODB’s “Shimmy Shimmy Ya”.

songs.title: Green Power

description.plain:
The concept of “Green Power” revolves around the use of the word “Green” as metonymy, “a word or phrase that is substituted for a more formal word or phrase to which it is related.”

In this case, “Green” primarily refers to weed and money, though the meaning changes later on in the song.

The first verse is a one-sided conversation between Quasimoto and an unidentified person about the pursuit of green in an urban community, while the second verse illuminates the listener to Madlib’s own alternative definition for the word.

“Green Power” could represent two things – the power of money (to control people) or the power of weed (to put someone under the influence). In  “Astro Black” (the song before “Green Power” on The Unseen), there is a sample where a man talks about “green power” – the definition was the power of money. However, on Yessir Whatever, the previous song is Sparkdala. Make of that what you will.

songs.title: Seasons Change

description.plain:
This excellent track was left off the Further Adventures of Lord Quas album because the hefty sample of “DC City” by Roy Ayers couldn’t be cleared in time.

It came out on a limited 7" single instead and eventually made it onto the compilation album Yessir Whatever.



The ending features a sample of Neil Diamond’s Pot Smoker’s Song.

songs.title: MHB’s

description.plain:
The sample used for the beat was “Little Children” by Kool and the Gang.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4cQ8_WsXnRg

However, Madlib’s ultimate inspiration is the song Ho Happy Jackie by AZ. “MHB’s” is most likely an allusion to the classic cut off of AZ’s 1995 debut album “Doe or Die”. The two songs share similar lyrical themes about manipulative women and share the same foundational sample.

songs.title: Am I Confused?

description.plain:
“I’m so confused! I don’t know what to do!” is sampled from the intro off of Organized Konfusion’s album Stress: The Extinction Agenda. On the intro, the clip appears fifty-five seconds in.

About the track, Pitchfork says:
“ Although the song "Astronaut” is a nice addition to Quas' catalog, the real gem here is the second track, “Am I Confused?” The title’s rhetorical question, which is repeated in the chorus, reflects the artist’s inner-turmoil as he deals with issues of self-destruction, loss, and community. Thematically speaking, this is one of his most self-reflective, complex and rewarding songs to date. Recalling Marvin Gaye’s classic “What’s Going On,” the song addresses Madlib’s feelings of confusion and helplessness as he witnesses the deterioration of his friends and family members. But whereas “What’s Going On” took a more reductionary, macrocosmic view, “Am I Confused?” suggests the ills that infect its inhabitants are a result of their own deeply embedded self-destructive urges. The song is populated with adulterous fathers and cancerous break-dancers, an AIDS-stricken sister and inner-city derelicts “drinkin' nightrain and pumpin' needles in their vein.” Throughout the song, Madlib constantly modulates his voice so that it appears there are numerous emcees on the track. This is a nice touch in that it lifts the veil of anonymity and breaches the gap between the two personas of Madlib and Quasimoto, suggesting that the tragedies described are something both sides of Otis Jackson can agree upon. The song’s production is anchored by a xylophone sample that’s a melancholy, downbeat slice of classic 70s soul– in other words, vintage Madlib."
